channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-13300] Fix casing in getTimeStamp() and setTimestamp() for Mutations
item.description: For some reason we have two ways of writing this method. It should be consistent.
item.summary: Fix casing in getTimeStamp() and setTimestamp() for Mutations

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

They are interfaces marked as InterfaceAudience.Public, I don't think it is necessary because users have to change their code when they upgrade their client. We should avoid incompatible as much as possible.
Ya same concern from my side as well.. Or else we should deprecate old getter against a new corrected method name.
Both ways are fine to me. We can either close this ticket or I can change the patch to deprecate the old method name.
+1 to change the patch here with deprecation. Also pls check within HBase code base usage of the wrong API name and make sure we no longer refer to deprecated API. Tks.
I updated the patch. It now deprecates the old getter and uses the new corrected version throughout the HBase codebase.

Lars George You ok with this boss? If so I will commit.

Sorry, what are the occurrences for get/setTimestamp()?
Seems that we are using mostly TimeStamp variation. 


  Get : public Get setTimeStamp(long timestamp)

  Mutation:  public long getTimeStamp()

Enis Soztutar I've gone through the code base before making the patch. It seems that both variations are used a lot. Within the Mutations classes the Delete class uses the lowercase version.


Delete : public Delete setTimestamp(long timestamp)

But I'm fine to change it to the uppercase version in the Mutations classes if this should be the version for consistency.
If you can please list all the declared method signatures, it will help us decide. If it is only Delete, I would rather fix it there.

I added an Excel sheet which shows the method declarations I could find, where either timestamp or timeStamp is used. I left out the test and example classes. The sheet shows that mostly timestamp is used throughout the declarations.
